title: Begum Zaffar Ali
text:
Begum Zaffar Ali, née Sahibzaadi Syeda Fatima, was the first woman matriculate of <a href="Kashmir">Kashmir</a> who went on to become Inspector of Schools in <a href="Kashmir">Kashmir</a>. She was an educationist, women's liberation activist, Deputy Director of education and later a legislator in the Indian state of <a href="Jammu%20and%20Kashmir%20%28state%29">Jammu and Kashmir</a>. She was associated with the activities of the <a href="All%20India%20Women%E2%80%99s%20Conference">All India Women’s Conference</a> and was its secretary before partition, but a chance meeting with <a href="Muhammad%20Ali%20Jinnah">Muhammad Ali Jinnah</a> and his sister, <a href="Fatima%20Jinnah">Fatima Jinnah</a> in <a href="Kashmir">Kashmir</a>, who would later visit the family for banquets, influenced her and she left the conference to concentrate her efforts in women's liberation movements in the pre-independent India.
Biography.
Begum Ali was born in 1901 to Khan Bahadur Aga Syed Hussain Thakur, Home and Judicial Minister during Maharaja <a href="Hari%20Singh">Hari Singh</a>'s rule.<ref name="libasapp.pakkapapita.com/?p=5452">[libasapp.pakkapapita.com/?p=5452]</ref> She began her career as a teacher in 1925 at the Girls' Mission High School(present day <a href="Mallinson%20Girls%20School">Mallinson Girls School</a>). A staunch believer in women’s rights, she went door to door to raise awareness regarding girls’ education in the Valley and persevered to empower them through education. Her speeches at Public events inspired adulation among the women who started sending their girls to schools. Begum was married to Agha Zaffar Ali Qizilbash, a scion of an aristocratic <a href="Afghans">Afghan</a> family settled in <a href="kashmir">kashmir</a>. The couple had three sons, Agha Nasir Ali-IAS, a civil servant who retired as Labour Secretary of India in 1977, <a href="Agha%20Shaukat%20Ali">Agha Shaukat Ali</a>, who joined civil services of <a href="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> during the partition of <a href="India">India</a> in 1947. Begum's youngest son is Agha Ashraf Ali, an academician who retired as Commissioner of Higher Education in <a href="Jammu%20and%20Kashmir%20%28state%29">Jammu and Kashmir</a> "The Veiled Suite: The Collected Poem", an anthology written by her grandson <a href="Agha%20Shahid%20Ali">Agha Shahid Ali</a>, a noted Kashmiri-American poet, features a poem in memory of her. The <a href="Government%20of%20India">Government of India</a> awarded her the fourth highest civilian honour of <a href="Padma%20Shri">Padma Shri</a> in 1987. Later in a <a href="Doordarshan">Doordarshan</a> interview, she announced to return the award in protest against the undemocratic policies of the Government. She moved to the United States in the 1990s and lived there with her son <a href="Agha%20Shaukat%20Ali">Agha Shaukat Ali</a> until her death in 1999.
